items.title: Media Notes #01
items.content_html:
This is a list of TV shows, movies, books and interesting music I consumed recently. The idea here is not to document every single thing in chronological order, but to list some of the things I watched, read, andÂ listened to that resonated with me.

Watched #

Pablo & LuisÃ£o season 1 #

This is the Brazilian equivalent of Everybody Hates Chris: a biographical series but even more absurd and hilarious. PauloÂ Vieira shows his poor upbringing with a focus on the relationship and mishaps between his father and his fatherâ€™s best friend. The kinds of stories that nobody believes to be true.

The Rehearsal season 2 #

As in Nathan for You, this show blurs the lines between whatâ€™s real and whatâ€™s not. After finishing it, I naively searched for more information about the last episode, but I soon realized thereâ€™s no point in doing that.

Taskmaster Australia season 3 #

Watching Taskmaster during dinner is our Friday night routine. This was anÂ atypical season as we didnâ€™t hate any of the contestants.

90-day FiancÃ© UK seasons 1-3 #

I was never a big reality TV fan, but that changed last year. Itâ€™s nice to analyze these absurd situations and reflect on whoâ€™s at fault in each one. Apart from that, no thinking is really necessary, and I can just unwind. IÂ know they are scripted and edited to inflate everything, but I just stopped caring.

LOL Brasil season 4 #

This is the season with Porta dos Fundos. I had some good laughs, butÂ overall I found the crass jokes were too frequent.

DaaaaaalÃ­! #

The only movie on the list, unfortunately. The trailer gave me the impression of a comedy, but all the good jokes fit into those 2 minutes. ItÂ was okay, or maybe it was me who didnâ€™t get it.

Read #

A Little Life by Hanya Yanagihara #

This was a hard one that took me almost 5 months to finish. I tend not to sympathize with the struggles of the super rich (and probably never will), but Judeâ€™s suffering will stay with me. Something that never crossed my mind before, but makes complete sense, is that the legal system exists to enforce laws as theyâ€™re written, not to deliver real justiceâ€”and sometimes the laws are not fair.

Breakfast of Champions by Kurt Vonnegut #

I remember I liked Catâ€™s Craddle when I read it 20 years ago, but this one didnâ€™t resonate with me. Maybe it wasnâ€™t a good idea to read this right after AÂ LittleÂ Life.

Yoga by Emmanuel CarrÃ¨re #

A book about yoga, meditation, depression, terrorism, and a humanitarian crisis. This was not what I expected but in a good way.

Listened to #

Alan Sparhawk with Trampled by Turtles #

This album is brutal. The grief of losing his lifelong partner, Mimi Parker, can be felt throughout. Screaming Song filled my eyes with tears more than once.

The Scholars by Car Seat Headrest #

I donâ€™t know how I havenâ€™t heard about Car Seat Headrest before. I went back to other albums and I really liked the experimentation. This new album is a rock opera that takes place in a fictional college named Parnassus University. The songs Gethsemane and Planet Desperation are my favorites, but being a rock opera, they are 11 and 19 minutes long.

Ni Ishanai ~ Floresta Futuro by Kayatibu #

Iâ€™ve been trying to listen to more diverse music: music that is not sung in English and is not Brazilian pop/rock. An episode of Alt.Latino featured the single Nai Basa Masheri by Kayatibu and Yaka Huni Kuin, which led me to Ni Ishanai. This album is unlike anything Iâ€™ve heard before. It alternates songs in Portuguese and in their native language, which as far as I can tell is Hantxa Kuin. The songs are mesmerizing and I highly recommend a listen.

As a side note, not only â€œworld musicâ€ is a bad term for this, but the fact that Nai Basa Masheri is classified as â€œPop in Spanishâ€ in Apple Music is infuriating.

items.title: Kerning in PowerPoint
items.content_html:
Microsoft Word expects kerning data in a GPOS table. PowerPoint expects it in an old style kern table. This is how I make it work in both apps.

In Glyphs, I first prepare my font using the Kern Flattener script by mekkablue. It will open a copy of the current document, turn all group kerning into glyph kerning and set some other parameters. I export this new document somewhere as TTF and close the file. Thereâ€™s no need to save it as it will not be needed anymore.

I then extract the kern table of the exported fonts as XML using ttx. The following Terminal command will do that for a couple of font files:

ttx -t kern -o SomeFont-Regular-kern.xml SomeFont-Regular.ttf
ttx -t kern -o SomeFont-Bold-kern.xml SomeFont-Bold.ttf

I donâ€™t like having a bunch of duplicate TTFs laying around to trip me up, so I immediately delete the fonts.

Back to the original glyphs file, I export the TTFs as usual. Then, it is time to merge the kern table extracted above with the final fonts. This is the Terminal command:

ttx -m SomeFont-Regular.ttf SomeFont-Regular-kern.xml
ttx -m SomeFont-Bold.ttf SomeFont-Bold-kern.xml

Alternatively, it is possible to merge a table into a font via Python script by creating an empty TTFont object, importing the XML into it and then copying the table over. Something like this:

from fontTools.ttLib import TTFont

ttf_file = "SomeFont-Regular.ttf"
kern_file = "SomeFont-Regular-kern.xml"

ttf_font = TTFont(ttf_file)
kern_font = TTFont()
kern_font.importXML(kern_file)
ttf_font["kern"] = kern_font["kern"]
ttf_font.save(ttf_file)

I have tested this with a font that has stylistic sets (unencoded glyphs) which have kerning values. Surprisingly, the kerning of those glyphs works in Word and does not affect the kerning in PowerPoint. This was tested to be working on:

  • version 2309 of Word and PowerPoint 365
  • version 16.78 of Word and PowerPoint for Mac

items.title: Month in review: October 2023
items.content_html:
Inspired by Melanie Richardsâ€™ Learning Logs, Iâ€™m starting this series to document things that happened to me each month. The reason Iâ€™m not calling it â€œlearning logsâ€ is that I feel Iâ€™m not very productive in the self-improvement area most of the time, so calling it a â€œmonth in reviewâ€ seems lighter on me. Iâ€™ll try my best to remember what I did each month and to keep this going. No promises, though.

October started with me and my wife making the down payment for our new apartment. We are still waiting on the bank to finish their part of the paperwork, but if it all goes well we should have a new home around the end of November.

Around the middle of the month there was a Fabio Haag Type team meetup. It was not as formal as I make it sound. We are a remote team, so it is nice to see one another face to face once in a while. We had lunches, beers and worked a little bit as well. It was very fun :)

On smaller news, itâ€™s been a while that my PS4 wouldnâ€™t boot and I finally took it to a repair shop for an evaluation. As I only used it to play Rocket League (which has become kinda toxic) or when we had guests, I didnâ€™t have interested in getting it fixed. Instead, I proposed an exchange of the bricked PS4 for a pair of Joyâ€‘Cons and they accepted. AÂ small win!

And towards the end of the month I restarted this blog and thatâ€™s something worth celebrating.

Reading #

Iâ€™ve been trying to ditch YouTube before bedtime and read a book instead. The problem is, depending on the book Iâ€™m reading, I get sleepy very quickly and it takes me ages to finish anything. As I have lunch by myself during the week, I figured I should take my Kindle with me and use that time to read as well. It has been very effective.

This month I finished reading the Truman Capoteâ€™s classic In Cold Blood. Capoteâ€™s retelling of the Holcomb murders is so detailed that I am sure at least half of the things he narrates did not really happen. But it was a nice read, regardless.

I also read the more recent memoir How to Murder Your Life by Cat Marnell. The autobiography of a high-functioning drug addict working on the fashion publishing industry, this one was a rollercoaster. The author herself recognizes thereâ€™s something about the downfall of rich privileged people that makes it hard for us to look away. Surprisingly a pageÂ turner.

Watching #

Weâ€™ve watched the first season of El Encargado (The One in Charge) andÂ have finally finished all seasons of Taskmaster!

I also finished the first season of The Bear. My favorite episode so far is episode 7, â€œReviewâ€. It was nice to watch a show that does not immediatly makes the main characters fall in love for each other. Letâ€™s hope it keeps it like that in the second season.

Listening #

The most recent songs Iâ€™ve added to my Deezer favorite tracks:

  • Popstar researching oblivion by Flotation Toy Warning
  • Happiness by Hobo Johnson
  • Hayloft II by Mother Mother
  • Left Hand Free by alt-J
  • Bitch by Allie X
  • Elephant Woman by Blonde Redhead
  • DNA by Anna F.

I grew tired of many of the podcasts I usually listen to, so I am giving them a break. On the other hand, Iâ€™m binge listening to If Books Could Kill and Iâ€™m loving it. They have a similar vibe to Underunderstood, which I like. And Iâ€™m also enjoying the latest episodes of Search Engine (the theme song is incredibly catchy).

Writing it all out, it looks like October was more eventful than my usual month. Letâ€™s see what November will bring!

items.title: I also â¤ï¸ Typography
items.content_html:
Today, some of my fonts were launched at I Love Typography. I used to spend hours and hours reading ILT back when I was in college. It was (and probably still is) the most complete blog on the topic. I mean, just take a look at the archive.

The last few years has seen the consolidation of loads of intellectual property in very few hands. You could almost say the font market is starting to look like a Mono... poly.

From my perspective, ILT brings a breath of fresh air into this market by being a more humane alternative to other big font distributors. I love that they have a curation of the products they sell and promote, plus their proprietary CEDARS+ search. Have you tried it? It is so powerful!

Iâ€™d like to thank Nadine Chahine for welcoming me so well to ILT. Iâ€™m so happy to be part of it!

items.title: Hello world, once again
items.content_html:
The enshittification of the web forces me to revive my blog.

Iâ€™ve been getting more and more uncomfortable giving my data to big corporations and not owning it. Not that I post much, because I donâ€™t. ButÂ it bothers meÂ still.

I like the idea of personal blogs and I figured this is something I should try again. Iâ€™ve been following some nice personal blogs and microblogs like Chris Coyier, Aegir, Adrianna Tan, Melanie Richards, and others. It was Matthias Ottâ€™s new project Own Your Web that pushed me towards restarting this site.

Iâ€™m not really sure how this is going to work, but letâ€™s see where this takesÂ me.
